review_title: Great place to work if you have a Phd, not so much if you don't.
pros:
As a lecturer at UCO, I teach without a PhD.  So while the institution declares itself a primarily teaching institution, I am not evaluated based on my teaching but instead on my research, which is next to impossible to complete without a PhD.  You can see where this is going…while I work hard, have positive student reviews and have positive outcomes on teaching, I’m passed over for promotions, not eligible for merit bonuses, and in general have no opportunities for advancements while faculty with PhD’s get tenure, are allowed to teach fewer students (i.e., work less) and make up to three times my salary.  Ok, this is the system in higher education, but as “teaching” institution and not a “research” institution it shouldn’t be this way.  

Ok, now on to the positives.  There are lots of things going for this school including a progressive management team, an environmental ethic, a desire to focus on leadership and civic engagement and other things to make it a good place to work.  In fact, if I ever had any hope of a promotion, I wouldn’t be quitting, but after seven years and no room to grow, I’ve decided to move on.  The upper leaders (President, Provost, etc) of the school have really impressed me but the system is stacked against someone with only a master’s degree so I’m out looking for a job.
cons: Promotions are not really merit based for faculty, more so on education completed.

pros: It is a convenient location and nice place for entry-level work.
cons: It really depends on the focus.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Edmond, OK
pros: Great environment, easy jobs, great work life Balance
cons: No cons really, nothing much too tell

review_title: Low salaries; Very political; Fun campus environment
pros: I worked at UCO off and on for about ten years. It is fun to be on the college campus, and you are encouraged to be involved. There are many opportunities for employees to interact with students and to work in cross-campus roles. It is enjoyable to work for a college because of the energy and engagement there. Some nice benefits are available because of the university environment, like library privileges, the work out center, free lunches around Broncho Lake sometime, free football games sometimes, and more.
cons: I found UCO to be very political. Some people moved up quickly there, and generally those were the people who were in the VP's pockets. One Assistant VP doesn't even have a college degree, but she covered for a VP for a few years and moved up. Other people work diligently and never see a promotion. Alternatively, if someone can't get along with others, you see them moved into a Director position where they do their own thing and have no direct reports. Salaries were very low when I was there. I know they have tried to make them better lately, but compared to the private sector, the salaries there are very low. In some areas, you aren't very busy, so the low salaries aren't as painful. But other areas require a ton of effort, time, and dedication, and you won't be monetarily rewarded.

pros: PTO, Family Environment, Professional Development
cons: Health Insurance, Wide Ranges in Salaries Across Campus

review_title: Good school, poor management and work environment
pros: Time off, school breaks, fun school events

review_title: It's true that UCO is one of the nation's Great Colleges to Work For (The Chronicle of Higher Education thinks so, too!)
job_title: Manager Employee Relations in Edmond, OK
pros: Working for this thriving metropolitan University is exceptionally rewarding, especially considering that it is the University's mission to help students learn and become productive and engaged citizens. That's something so meaningful to me, and I feel good everyday knowing that I am contributing to an endeavor that's so worthwhile. The quality of life we enjoy as UCO employees is truly second to none. Not only are we able to achieve that elusive work/life balance that so many people seek in their place of employment, we also have one of the most generous benefits packages around, we have countless opportunities for professional development and career advancement, we promote and embrace an atmosphere of diversity and inclusion, we work in an environment of collegiality where creativity is embraced and new ideas have the freedom to flourish, and we have the good fortune to work on a beautiful, historical campus. In UCO, I have found my professional home.
cons: I truly cannot think of anything negative to say about UCO as an employer.

review_title: Dead end for 95% of employees careers! You will finish in the same place you start, with the same pay.
pros: Two weeks off for Christmas. One week off for Spring Break. No overtime for hourly employees.
cons: Pay, UCO pays 85% of market value for a position, as its policy demands. Almost no room for advancement. Supervisors look to keep you were you are, they do not try to grow you as an employee. There are rifts between most divisions and the Office of Information Technology. There hiring policies are a joke, the good ole boy system is in effect. UCO doesn't respect your educational background, they would rather hire people with high school diplomas and a few certificates over degree holders, to care for the students that are earning their higher education.

review_title: Don't question things, be a proud Broncho, make the right friends, and you will be fine
pros: Many dedicated colleagues who love the university, good university atmosphere with activities and events often, free fitness center membership, free parking, tuition benefit, new president hopefully will make some good changes.
cons: Bureaucratic, IT department gets in the way of things, the leadership team is out of touch, yes people are valued while those that question things are not, promotions seem random and are based on who you are friends with rather than true skill or ability, there is a lot of administrative bloat and some people are working really hard while others barely work.

pros: This is the largest undergraduate university in the state serving the central Oklahoma metro area.  The chemistry department offers one of the best undergraduate degree plans in the state, with extensive hands-on small class sized learning.   We also have the best chemical instrumentation for undergraduates in the state, complete with extensive hands-on experience on how to use them.  We also offer undergraduate research that can lead to peer review publications before you graduate!
cons: As with all universities in the US, because of the desire to give tax breaks to the wealthy and corporations, the state has continuously cut funding to the university producing a burden on the students, and making higher education more expensive for the average citizen.

pros: Co-Workers are very welcoming.  UCO offers very comprehensive on-board training  which is a definite plus for getting your career off to a good start.  They really want you to progress and learn and offer tons of professional development classes throughout the year.  They reward hard work and like to promote from within.  Great paid holiday schedule, especially if you have school-aged children.  Good benefits- health, life, retirement, tuition reimbursement for yourself and family.
cons: Hard to get hired. They have tons of applicants for each job (because it is a great place to work).  Count yourself very lucky if you do get hired.  Don't give up if you don't.  Apply for everything you think you are qualified for.

review_title: Great people and benefits but little opportunity for advancement.
pros: Good benefit package, with time off for holidays, teacher's retirement plan, free membership to Wellness Center. Some tuition assistance. Nice and friendly community.
cons: Higher level positions are very competitive and internal candidates are often overlooked (unless you are one of the "favorites"). Many good and talented people leave for this reason. On the other hand, some people who have been there forever are not held accountable and do little work--very frustrating. Not an easy place to "work your way up." Silo mentality across campus and serious communication problems with upper management.

pros: Great campus, close to everything in town, traffic is reasonable, no charge for parking in staff lots, generous vacations and friendly folks everywhere you go. UCO pays for the employee's health insurance (family is extra) and membership to the wellness center is free - active campus, lots going on.
cons: Salary bumps are hard to come so ask for as much as you can going in. That said, the vacation time, encouraging environment and great people almost make up for it. Parking is horrible and getting worse the more buildings that go up in former parking lots. Something needs to be done but nothing is on the horizon. Get used to walking, but hey, you may get your 10,000 steps just going to and from your car!

pros: I started working at UCO because of my long and sometimes hazardous daily commute to the South side of OKC.  Starting at the bottom. I have able to advance to a job that I love.  There are many advantages provided by UCO for employees, they offer professional education courses, both online and in the classroom.  They constantly strive to help one seek annual goals of achievement. Of course, one of the best perks is that we are off between Christmas and New Year's Day allowing us to have more time for family.  Less stress.  I have made many life long friends with the staff and students.
cons: For younger people, it would be salary and compensations.

review_title: Great perks, even for Higher Education!
pros: UCO has a great atmosphere for staff due to the positive leadership on campus focusing on a balanced life, student learning, and community involvement. The leadership values innovation, positive change, and creativity in work processes.  Free parking, free gym membership, campus activities, release time for working out and community service, and extra paid vacation days are all added bonuses.
cons: Because we are not the flagship university for the state, finances can be an issue. This reveals itself through lower salaries, older (though well-maintained) buildings, and limited technology. Also, adding dependents on your medical insurance is very expensive.

review_title: Overall great university to work for
pros: You really feel valued as an employee here. They have staff appreciation events, employee awards, and a lot of great extras for employees. Benefits are also great compared to other places in the area. This is one of the only universities I know of in Oklahoma that actually let their staff park for free on campus and we get free access to our wellness center. And that's in addition to more paid holidays. There are also great professional development opportunities. It is very encouraged to take advantage of opportunities to grow both personally and professionally here. We also get a pretty thorough orientation and training when we first start that includes basic policies and procedures as well as a tour of campus, which I found really helpful since I didn't go to school here. I also love that we are at the forefront of sustainability and lean processes among other universities in the state. So it really feels like a university that cares in a variety of ways.
cons: Salary is probably one of the worst things, but it's not that far off than other universities I have worked for. Sometimes it feels like some departments are valued more than others so you can get the feeling that your work is not deemed as important. Not every department has a good structure for advancement. You can work somewhere for years and not hear the word promotion. Most of the time you have to apply for a higher position and compete against internal and external candidates for it. And there is no guarantee that you will get the position over an external candidate.

job_title: Cashier In the Bursar's Office in Edmond, OK
pros: I really like the staff in my office, we are like a family.  I enjoy visiting with the students and learning about their hopes and dreams for the future.  I get the opportunity to visit with students every day.  Compensation is much more than just dollars you have to consider all benefits.  The employees insurance is paid by the Universtiy, we are allowed to use the Wellness Center and then there's GET'EM.  Time off is wonderful we have 3 days at Thanksgiving, 2 weeks at Christmas and a week at Spring break.  These are in addition to our normal vacation and sick days and Martin Luther King, Memorial Day, 4th of July, and Labor Day.
cons: I really don't have much as far as cons.  The values of the company are to give the students an education and to prepare them for their chosen careers.  My immediate leadership is great as well as up the ladder.  Since I've been here there hasn't been any decissions made that have not made for a better benefit for the employees.

pros: Lots of changes and expansion into new areas of the city, new technologies, teaching methods, etc. It's exciting to be part of a campus that is looking towards the future and not dwelling in the past. I get along well with colleagues and I never have to take work home with me. There are ample opportunities to be involved in both job-specific and campus-wide committees. Excellent benefits.
cons: Compensation is slightly less than I would make at the same position elsewhere in the state, but, so far, the atmosphere and people almost make up for it.

review_title: Excellent place to work, with poor compensation.
job_title: Coordinator of Graphic Design in Edmond, OK
pros: Fun work environment, with plenty of opportunities to be involved. Great variety of projects, with loads of creative freedom. Very flexible schedule with emphasis on family life.
cons: The pay is very low, having to work a part-time job as well just to pay the bills. There are a lot academic politics, where people get to do their own thing because they have tenure or they "know someone." Lots of dated processes, because of politics. Very limited resources due to small budgets.

review_title: UCO will always be home to me.
pros: I am a UCO graduate, and I was excited to return to UCO as an administrative assistant for an academic department. I enjoy my work environment, and I have had wonderful interactions with colleagues all across campus. Also, there are numerous benefits available to full-time employees. This university truly cares about the well-being of both its students and employees.
cons: I don't think I received adequate training or guidance for my position immediately after I was hired, but I was able to learn more about policies and procedures as time passed.

review_title: This is an excellent place to work and to attend for school.
job_title: Undergraduate Research Assistant in Edmond, OK
pros: This is an expanding university. The culture there isn't typical for a regional university in Oklahoma. The faculty and staff are very helpful and very nice. This is probably the top undergraduate research institution in the state.
cons: The location isn't great for an undergraduate student looking for a true college experience. Although Edmond is a nice, safe area, it isn't very diversity-friendly. Though the university itself is.

job_title: International Programming Manager in Edmond, OK
pros: Empowered me to lead the program to plan and execute 20 events. Gave me opportunity to lead a group of 30 student leaders on campus. Developed cross-cultural communication sills and learned how to promote program and events.
cons: I did not have any bad experiences while employed. At times there may be some disagreements but it was resolved very fast. Overall it was a good experience.

pros: Given the ability to learn and teach others my discipline. Lots of cultural activities on campus. The campus environment, fountain, cafeteria, onsite gym, Melton Art Gallery are all wonderful perks of working at UCO!
cons: No prior formal teaching experience, other than on the corporate level. Received negative feedback from some students. Employment only lasted one semester. Employment is higher in fall than spring and I needed a job that would last.

job_title: Computer Lab Assistant in Edmond, OK
pros: This school is a great place to work for any students. The hours are extremely flexible, in fact, they work entirely around your class schedule every semester. It is a relaxed environment, where you get to meet new students in your field of study.
cons: There weren't too many cons about working at UCO. I was only a student worker so the pay was minimum wage. Sometimes they try to hire too many people, which ends up cutting down hours for EVERYONE from 20-25 to 5-10 hours a week.

pros: UCO has its own police force which has a constant presence on campus -- every day of the year and every hour of the day. UCO police officers serve the campus community in the same manner and with the same authority and responsibility as other local law enforcement agencies, with the added benefit of being service-minded.
cons: Emergency 911 calls are routed through the Edmond Police dispatch. They then notify UCO Police as well as Fire and Ambulance services. However, this does not delay prompt response.

review_title: Great benefits make up for not much room for advancement
pros: great benefits--holidays off, tuition waiver, good insurance for employees (although expensive for spouses/family); great education atmosphere and opportunities!
cons: Not much room for advancement, don't see much accountability for upper management, silo mentality, promotions/opportunities definitely depend on who you know

pros: Work-Life Balance, Benefits, Culture - The Work life balance is the number one reason to work here along with the Culture. You receive 15 days of vacation along with all of the holidays that the university is closed. All in all its 6 plus weeks of time off. It's also really rewarding to come to work knowing that you are serving students who are seeking an education. It's the best kind of mission to work towards.
cons: There are no major cons

review_title: Great college, good masters degree job
pros: UCO is a great institution for higher education.  You can actually be proud of the product your taking to students.
cons: Low salary. Travel. competency of management. At the end of the day it's an entry level position.

pros: Caring people to work with all over campus. Will give you support when in need whether work related or personal life.
cons: The only cons I can come up with is the fact that there are too many silos on campus causing communication to be poor outside oh those areas

pros: Wonderful work environment, wonderful caring people that want you to grow and expand yur knowledge. Not content with the status quo. It is a place with the attitude "We can always grow and be better."
cons: Parking! And, traffic in Edmond!

review_title: Great for undergraduate students who want a flexible employer that work with student class schedules.
pros: UCO works well with student workers. They understand that students are in college to get a degree and are more than willing to work with your class schedule.
cons: One downside for a student work is that you can not work full time. Student workers generally get close to minimum so pay is low.

pros: The best thing about this job is the flexibility. I can adjust my work schedule to fit around other things.
cons: The challenges of this job include having to find things to do to stay busy. This job requires personal motivation and initiative .

pros: The administration deeply cares about the well being of the faculty and staff, and goes above and beyond to serve the faculty and students.
cons: Despite the low cost of living in Oklahoma, the pay at this university is relatively low, especially when compared to our peer institutions in the state, region, and country.

pros:
-Great people and supervisors
-For the most part the work enviornment was consistently positive
-Students
-UCO has great vacation time for holidays
cons:
-As with any organiztion, sometimes communication between departments needed improvement
-Sometimes decision making among upper-administration needed to be more firm

review_title: Great place to work if your a brown noser.
pros: Friendly professors and teaching staff ok benefits lots of time off for holidays and bad weather.students are fun to be around and really nice.
cons: little to no chance of promotion or raises unless you brown nose or know the right people. lazy employee,s that are almost impossible to fire physical plant employee,s are worked to death and treated like criminals.little to no drug screening process too many pot head losers.

review_title: Fun and creative work, but requires special skills.
job_title: Costume Shop Student Assistant in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: The job provides a create outlet. Work stays at work, but it can get really busy during shows. It's a great position for technical theatre students.
cons: The hours are minimal, and there are no benefits. You have to know what you are doing or else you will be doing less fun things.

pros: The University is a great place to work. People are very friendly and generally want to see faculty/staff/students succeed. Benefits are very good and you can't beat the time off.
cons: Pay can be on the low side. Academics usually pays less than the corporate field. And, with the State of Oklahoma budget crisis things are getting worse.

review_title: UCO's Continuing Education Program is a BAD JOKE!
pros: UCO  itself is an excellent place to work across campus....but NOT in Continuing Education. This department suffers from poor leadership, arrogance, and lack of academic understanding. The main point of this department and its leadership is financial.... not the well being of students or clients.
cons:
Continuing Education is the worst managed, narcissistic department on campus.
TERRIBLE,. Department leadership has problems with ego,  Uncommunicative. Backstabbing. Does not understand the academic world of a university.

job_title: Director of Operations in Edmond, OK
pros: The campus environment is a friendly, family/team oriented group.
cons: The campus is rapidly growing.  Often, new and existing job responsibilities are lost in the transition periods.

review_title: My experience has been great so far. Small town feeling
pros: Work life balance, the ability to do my work and still be afforded the opportunity to engage with my own children's activities and school functions.
cons: Would like to see the pay be more competitive

pros: All people mean well. It is friendly environment. Work life balance is great. Some aspects are top notch
cons: Many aspects are dated, underfunded, not well respected. Reputation is not good in community and academic standards are poor

job_title: Student Setup Technician (Weekend) in Edmond, OK
pros:
Consistent 21-25 hours during the school year, 25-35 hours in the summer. 

They work with your class schedule. 

Time to do homework. 

Easy work.
cons:
Some groups can be troublesome.

Late nights for a student.

It's physical labor - light labor sometimes, but it can get rough.

pros: Benefits are great. Lots of time off.
cons: Little opportunity for advancement. Pay is low compared to other positions of equal responsibility in the non-academic world. State government does not value higher education.

pros:
Many knowledgeable people to gain experience from. 
Lot of variety of opportunities for different careers.
Convenient place to be if you're continuing your education.
cons:
Availability of work hours can vary year to year for students.
Pay isn't strongly competitive.
Parking is a nightmare during most hours of the day.

review_title: 3rd largest university in the state with the heart of the 1st
job_title: Manager of Video Services in Edmond, OK
pros: As every university should, UCO shows strong focus on academic programs and faculty. Great PTO opportunities.
cons: Staff pay could be considered lower than average, however this varies by department and is in many ways offset by benefit opportunities.

review_title: Don't expect a lot of support at the bottom
pros: Pay, benefits, a lot of the people are decent human beings
cons: Major disconnects between upper management and the workers

pros: University of Central Oklahoma is a great place to work at. Edmond is also a great place to live in.
cons: the housing price is expensive. It is not easy for a teacher to buy a house in Edmond. Living cost is high.

review_title: Excellent university that is moving in the right direction.
pros: Cares about students, faculty and staff. Gathers input from all to make improvements.
cons: Making the right moves sometimes takes longer than expected.

review_title: Great place for student to hone soft skills
pros: Works with class schedule. Work at the same place you have class.
cons: Takes a lot of time so time management skills is a must.

pros:
Friendly faculty and staff
Great place to grow
Large community with a small-town feel
Networking opportunities
cons:
Not very timely when working with other departments ("your problem, not mine" mentality)
Prone to little mistakes, attention to detail lacking 
Low pay for work load

job_title: Consultant/Chef De Projet Gouvernance Et Qualité in Edmond, OK
pros: Great school with good leadership in administration. Lots of new buildings and facility upgrades.
cons: No major cons, maybe just the school politics which is common at the university level.

pros: they are very nice and  friendly people .
cons: you have to sit at the desk forver and be there at like 6 in the morning then turn around and go to your classes

pros: Great leave benefits.  Good medical.  Nice company to work for.
cons: Advancement is difficult.  Salaries are not competitive.

pros: Best part of this is working with the right people. It makes your job easier
cons: Know your material or project well, just in case one member can't step up

cons: Compensation evaluations need to be more frequent at this institution.

pros: I have been a student, a student-worker, and I currently hold a staff position. good place to work, but results vary by department and expertise.

review_title: Excellent place to work as a student
pros: The atmosphere on campus is great and the supervisors are awesome

pros: People are very nice in UCO campus, they help you in the different tasks assigned. And help you to grow professionally.

cons: As a student, 20 hours is the max amount you can work

pros: Wonderful coworkers and department head.
